Statement.paragraph: Summary of Damages Prevented by Potential LTFS Projects

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: The following figure summarizes the estimated damages prevented by the potential LTFS local protection projects, combined with a 20% flow reduction on the Red River main stem. Prevented damages are estimated for 100 year, 200 year and 500 year floods.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Prevented damages are computed for both (1) baseline hydrology, or that currently used by the USACE and (2) wet period hydrology, or that recommended by the current USACE feasibility study for Fargo-Moorhead flood protection.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Depending on the hydrology used, damages prevented by the potential LTFS projects will range from about $3 to [$]4 billion for a single 100 year flood, from $6.5 to [$]8 billion for a single 200 year flood, and from $10 to [$]13 billion for a single 500 year flood.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Working together with sound, proactive floodplain management, the potential LTFS projects can make a profound, measureable difference far into the future for the Red River basin. ------------------------------------------------------------------------ Total Prevented Damages of Potential LTFS Projects--Red River Basin Part IV: Moving Ahead With Integrated Action 10 Conclusions and Recommendations for Action

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: The basin of the Red River of the North, historically subject to widespread chronic flooding, regularly sustains millions of dollars in economic damages for each flood event. The Red River Basin Commission (RRBC) identified the following conclusions on structural and nonstructural strategies needed for permanent flood solutions in the basin and recommendations for action for states (individually and collectively) and the Federal Government to consider as they fund and implement Long Term Flood Solutions (LTFS) for the Red River Basin in Minnesota and North Dakota. These recommendations are built around the basin-wide LTFS ``Level of Protection Goals'' adopted by the RRBC in 2010 together with related flood risk reduction needs. The recommendations aim to move basin leaders from the usual response of reacting to the most recent major flood experience to a proactive, long-term plan with appropriate protection levels basin wide. If implemented, these recommendations will significantly reduce the risk of flood damages, and minimize disruption and economic loss and thus facilitate and expedite recovery after spring and summer floods.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: These recommendations cannot be successful without the dedicated local, state and Federal participation in funding and commitment to implement. 1. Immediate Needs/Critical Risks: Fargo-Moorhead, Devils Lake <bullet> Under current conditions, the Fargo-Moorhead metropolitan

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: area could get, in a major 500 year level flood, $9 to $10

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: billion or more in basin damages, according to the USACE. <bullet> Current levels of protection for Fargo-Moorhead are

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: inadequate. Protection should be increased to enable a

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: successful 500 year flood fight. <bullet> Protection measures for Fargo-Moorhead should be

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: economically viable and provide the least level of adverse

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: impacts to others. <bullet> A diversion of the Red River around Fargo-Moorhead would

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: provide the protection needed to endure a successful 500 year

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: flood fight if it were supplemented by retention and other

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: available options to achieve the RRBC's proposed LTFS level of

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: protection goals. <bullet> Retention to achieve the potential 20 percent flow reduction

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: on the main stem should be aggressively pursued upstream of

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Fargo-Moorhead to decrease the duration, scope, and level of

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: floods in the Fargo-Moorhead area, downstream communities, and

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: rural areas.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Recommendation for Action 1.1

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: The flood protection trajectory that has increased protection in the Fargo-Moorhead metro area since the 2009 flood should continue. State and Federal funds, with local government cost share, should continue supporting ongoing dike construction, property acquisitions, flowage easements, and flood infrastructure projects to be able to fight at least a 100 year flood, and upwards of a 500 year flood in the long-term.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Recommendation for Action 1.2

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Progress towards the proposed $1.77 billion diversion should be continued utilizing local, state, and Federal funds so that, combined with current flood protection strategies, this community will have the capacity within 10 years to wage a successful flood fight equal to or greater than the LTFS 500 year flood.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Recommendation for Action 1.3

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Retention upstream of the Hickson and Abercrombie stream gage for a flow reduction of 20 percent (minimum) should be advanced with shared funding by the F-M flood Diversion Authority working with local and joint water boards, using city, local, state, and Federal funds.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Recommendation for Action 1.4

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Leaders in state government in North Dakota and Minnesota, along with key local government officials and with input from the Diversion Authority and Federal agencies, should convene by early 2012 to determine the non-Federal cost share formula for the Locally Preferred Plan ($1.77 billion) diversion, and related $3.5 million operational estimates. <bullet> Rising levels of water in the Devils Lake region have

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: increased the potential for a natural overflow that could

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: discharge approximately 14,000 cubic feet per second (cfs) of

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: water into the Sheyenne River, triggering prolonged flooding

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: and catastrophic downstream water quantity and quality problems

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: in the Sheyenne and Red Rivers. This crisis should continue to

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: be addressed with immediate local, state and Federal action.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Recommendation for Action 1.5

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: The recommendations developed by the Devils Lake Executive Committee through the work of the Devils Lake Collaborative Working Group should continue to be supported by the state of North Dakota, local authorities, and Federal and Tribal governments to guard against critical risks.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Recommendation for Action 1.6

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: The RRBC and IRRB should distribute information with downstream interests and jurisdictions providing progress and timelines on Devils Lake activities.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Recommendation for Action 1.7

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: A comprehensive model using real-time data to determine the effects of releases of Devils Lake water via the various outlet channels on the Sheyenne and Red Rivers should be examined by local leaders and state and Federal agencies to determine needs and related costs. The examination should include the integration of various models already in use by the USGS, the NWS, the NDSWC, and the USACE and be facilitated by the RRBC. 2. Cornerstone Solutions: Floodplain Management

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: 2A Floodplain Management--Nonstructural Strategies <bullet> A majority of the basin population lives adjacent to the Red

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: River main stem and its tributaries at the lowest geographic

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: elevation subject to flooding with no comprehensive, basin-wide

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: approach to floodplain management, nor is there a mechanism to

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: align the variations in local, state, and Federal rules,

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: regulations, and approaches. <bullet> Nonstructural floodplain management strategies should be an

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: integral component of reducing flood damage risks in the basin. <bullet> The most effective overall technique for living with floods

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: is for basin citizens to take personal responsibility for their

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: own flood risk and for the sustainability of our natural

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: resources. <bullet> Minnesota and North Dakota should fund and administer flood

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: mitigation policy consistently throughout the Red River basin

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: so that a flood event in excess of the 100 year becomes the

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: benchmark for managing the risk of flooding, regulating

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: development in the floodplain, and for developing flood risk

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: reduction projects around existing and newly developed areas.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Recommendation for Action 2A.1

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: State floodplain regulations and local zoning ordinances should contain criteria for new residential, commercial, industrial, and agribusiness development that requires the largest of the following protection standards: <bullet> 100 year flood plus 3. <bullet> 200 year flood plus 1. <bullet> flood of record plus 1.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Recommendation for Action 2A.2

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Buildings located in at-risk areas where structural measures cannot accomplish the recommended flood protection levels or are not economically feasible should be publicly acquired and removed over the next 3 to 5 years.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Recommendation for Action 2A.3

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Local governments in the basin should update floodplain ordinances in the next 3 years, not permit new development in areas of high risk of flooding immediately adjacent to the Red River and tributaries, and minimize the use of variances, unless protected by elevation or another acceptable FEMA strategy.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Recommendation for Action 2A.4

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: A review of basic floodplain regulations and programs should be undertaken by appropriate agencies and stakeholders of local, state and Federal standards, to include:

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: 2A.4.1 An evaluation of the appropriate standards and

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: regulations for development throughout the basin, including the

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: adequacy of the 100 year regulatory minimum standard (to

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: include FIRMS) and the consideration of future standards to

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: reduce losses;

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: 2A.4.2 An analysis of community and state compliance with

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: the flood insurance program, to include an analysis of proposed

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: mandatory flood insurance for structures protected by dikes,

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: identification of impediments to, and potential tools and

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: resources for, participation in FEMA's community Rating System,

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: determination of the feasibility of insurance development, and

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: a strategy to prompt a basin-wide reduction in flood insurance

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: rates;

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: 2A.4.3 An analysis of the use of variances by local

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: governments; the reasons for and consequences of using

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: variances for individuals, communities, and state; and most

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: effective way(s) to track and document the use of variances.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Recommendation for Action 2A.5

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Every community and county in the basin should work toward joining or improving their rating through the national FEMA Community Rating System to achieve lower flood insurance premiums for their residents (40-45 percent discounts) by 2015 as part of their mitigation plan update.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Recommendation for Action 2A.6

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: A Floodplain Bill of Rights, to include a floodplain map and flooding history, should be developed by RRBC with local government, realtors, builders, developers, FEMA, and state agency participation (2012).

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Recommendation for Action 2A.7

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: RRBC should develop education materials on the floodplain related to the floodplain, insurance, personal decisions, and the Floodplain Bill of Rights, to be distributed to the public, realtors, lenders, and others (2012).

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Recommendation for Action 2A.8

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: The USACE nonstructural assessment of identified structures has been completed for the F-M diversion project along the main stem in six counties deemed economically feasible for nonstructural mitigation.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: 2A.8.1 The USACE should expand its assessment along the

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: entire main stem.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: 2A.8.2 A local sponsor should be identified to provide the

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: non-Federal cost share of 35 percent and implement the

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: mitigation in the next 3 to 5 years.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: 2A.8.3 Congress should authorize such a project and

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: appropriate approximately $12 million in funding for the 65

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: percent Federal cost share to mitigate.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Recommendation for Action 2A.9

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Minnesota and North Dakota should use their respective state Silver Jackets (Flood and Hazard Mitigation) teams to regularly communicate issues regarding flood mitigation efforts in the Red River Basin. Silver Jackets team members from Minnesota and North Dakota should contribute to a collaborative interstate strategy for flood recovery and projects for mitigation efforts for the Red River of the North basin, to be coordinated with the RRBC and others as deemed appropriate.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: 2B Floodplain Management--Raising Levels of Protection <bullet> Comprehensive and strategic level of protection goals are

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: needed for the entire basin. To this point, existing levels of

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: protection have been based most often on the most recent flood

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: experience, political will, and funding availability. <ctr-circle> The Minnesota and North Dakota legislatures should use

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: the RRBC Level of Flood Protection Goals as a guide to future

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: basin flood risk reduction strategies. (See ``Level of Flood

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Protection Goals'' adopted by the RRBC Board (2010) in LTFS

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Report, Ch. 8. Analysis assumes required freeboard.[)]

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Major Urban/Metropolitan Areas <ctr-circle> Fargo-Moorhead (see Section 1. Biggest Risks). <bullet> Grand Forks-East Grand Forks. Over the next 20 to 25 years,

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Minnesota and North Dakota should support increasing protection

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: to a 500 year flood level for Grand Forks-East Grand Forks by

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: improving the cities' current 200 to 250 year protection with

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: upstream retention that achieves the potential minimum 20

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: percent flow reduction on the Red River main stem at Grand

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Forks. <bullet> Winnipeg has elevated its level of protection to 700 years

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: by recent expansion of their diversion following the 1997

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: flood. Since its construction and subsequent first use in 1969,

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: the floodway has operated over 20 times and prevented more than

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: $10 billion in flood damages. This model shows the importance

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: of long range planning to realize the protection required from

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: potential large floods.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Recommendation for Action 2B.1

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Grand Forks and East Grand Forks should each request the 500 year or greater level of protection through the appropriate state and Federal legislative avenues. Planning should recognize the degree to which the strategy of retention can assist in achieving this level of protection for the two cities.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Recommendation for Action 2B.2

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: The RRBC shall facilitate an exchange between officials in Winnipeg, Manitoba, and Fargo-Moorhead local government officials, the F-M Diversion Authority, and the public for the purpose of sharing Winnipeg's experiences and expertise on the development and expansion of that city's diversion, including engineering, construction, and operation and maintenance of the Red River Floodway.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Critical Infrastructure: <bullet> Critical infrastructure needs to be protected from flooding

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: to the greatest levels practical. If adversely affected by

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: flooding, infrastructure such as water and waste water

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: facilities, airports, hospitals, transportation, regional

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: communications facilities, or chemical storage sites can

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: experience major disruptions, resulting in harm to the people,

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: economy, and environment of the basin.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Recommendation for Action 2B.3

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Over the next 3 to 5 years, state emergency management officers shall facilitate the identification and documentation of at-risk critical basin infrastructure and report to the state legislatures in the annual LTFS update.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Small Cities and Municipalities: <bullet> By 2015, cities in Minnesota and North Dakota on the main

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: stem, tributaries, and in other flood prone areas should

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: achieve protection to the 100 year level or 3 of freeboard the

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: largest flood in their area plus 3 of freeboard, whichever is

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: greater. <bullet> Once cities have achieved this level of protection,

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: additional protection should be pursued towards achieving

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: greater than 200 year flood protection using upstream

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: retention. Flood flow reduction from upstream retention can

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: further complement the current levees and other strategies

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: underway or contemplated.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Recommendation for Action 2B.4

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Community structural projects in collaboration with the RRWMB and RRJWRD should be funded in the next state funding cycle for each respective state. See attached funding timeline table D-31 and Level of Protection Appendix D, D-3.1, p. 12 with state, local and Federal funding.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Rural Residences and Farmsteads:

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Funding ring dikes or elevating of buildings for rural residents and farmsteads in flood prone areas should protect to 3 above the 100 year level or 3 above the largest flood in their area, whichever is greater.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Recommendation for Action 2B.5

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Structural projects identified in collaboration with the RRWMB and RRJWRD for rural areas, including ring dikes and rural property acquisitions, should be funded beginning in the next state funding cycle through 2015 for each respective state. For those projects that become necessary only after future floods, funding shall become available in subsequent funding cycles. See attached funding table D-31 and Level of Protection Appendix D, D-3.1, p. 12.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: farms experiencing composite net returns of $3 billion or more

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: annually. <bullet> Adequate drainage, whether surface or tile, is crucial to

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: crop production in the basin. <bullet> Studies such as the timing analysis study suggest that

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: improvements to drainage systems in areas that contribute

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: consistently to the rising side of the Red River flood

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: hydrograph (early water) have the potential to help reduce Red

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: River flood peaks if they can move runoff through the system

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: ahead of flood peaks. (Minnesota Flood Damage Reduction

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Workgroup Technical Paper No. 11) <bullet> At this time, no comprehensive, systematic approach exists

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: to coordinate the release of water in the current drainage

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: system based upon this timing analysis. Recent improvements in

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: modeling, flow data, and elevation data can be utilized to

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: better manage water to reduce flooding on the Red River. <bullet> The strategies that slow water or hold it on the land

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: slightly longer (while allowing for timely movement in the

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: drainage system) are best implemented through land use and

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: easement programs that take into account landowner impacts, as

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: well as benefits to the local area the main stem. <bullet> Potential exists to appropriate new Federal funding for land

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: management to the basin through the next U.S. farm bill that

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: will assist landowners in reducing runoff, reducing erosion,

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: and improving water quality. This effort will come through

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: programs administered by the Natural Resource Conservation

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Service or its designee.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Recommendation for Action 2B.6

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: The RRRA, RRWMB, and RRJWRD, with appropriate state agencies, local government, and commodity group participation and support, should develop a multipurpose drainage strategy for agricultural land that evaluates the following:

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: 2.10.1 Designed and engineered for both private benefits and

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: public water management objectives.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: 2.10.2 Temporary detention (slowing down of water) by land

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: management practices and land use changes.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: 2.10.3 Side inlet controls for all ditches.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: 2.10.4 Use of drainage for peak flow reductions and erosion

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: control.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: 2.10.5 Rate and volume of water related to field and drain

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: capacity.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: 2.10.6 Timing and movement of water in an equitable manner.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: 2.10.7 Landowner incentives and needs.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: 2.10.8 Adding drainage components to hydrologic models.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: 2.10.9 Need for studies, strategies, moratoriums, and

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: additional information.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Recommendation for Action 2B.7

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: River channel maintenance such as snagging and clearing of trees, including the removal of trees that have or are at risk of falling into rivers and waterways, should be continued as necessary to maintain open waterways systems. The two states should continue to fund this effort: under current policies, North Dakota at its level of about $1 to $2 million, and Minnesota to restore its historic level of $150,000 per year.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Recommendation for Action 2B.8

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: For purposes of achieving long-term flood retention and other benefits, Minnesota should provide state funding through bonding of $10 million a biennium for the Red River basin through the Board of Water and Soil Resources for Reinvest In Minnesota (RIM) easements to match or supplement Federal USDA conservation funding such as the Wetland Reserve Program, Conservation Reserve Program, EWP, and Environmental Quality Assurance Programs to achieve long term flood retention to leverage Federal funding in the next 5 year farm bill and for other benefits.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Recommendation for Action 2B.9

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: A basin wetland bank whereby farmers/landowners can purchase and exchange wetland credits should be developed by Minnesota, North Dakota, and South Dakota in partnership with NRCS and the local joint water resource districts in North Dakota and joint watershed districts in Minnesota.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Recommendation for Action 2B.10

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: middle, and late zones.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: and enforced at the local level for all natural, altered, and

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: man-made waterways to a minimum of 16.5 (1 rod) and a maximum

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: of 50 or more with incentives provided to landowners to reduce

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: sediment for water quality and maintenance cost benefits and to

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: slow the flow of water into the waterways.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Recommendation for Action 2B.11

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: The rural flood control systems that protect agricultural productivity and the economy from spring and summer floods should continue to be implemented throughout the basin. The goal is to reduce crop loss and to reduce planting delays by moving water off of land by mid-May in the spring and maximize flood control designs for peak run off for a 24 hour summer rainfall event with a 10 year reoccurrence interval.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Critical Transportation System and Emergency Services: <bullet> The Red River basin covers approximately 45,000\2\ miles or

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: 28 million acres, a majority directly in active agricultural

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: production, with an extensive system of highways, roads, and

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: bridges that provide for the movement of goods and people to

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: enhance the economic output of the region. <bullet> The RRBC should facilitate discussions with regional

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: organizations, state and Federal departments of transportation,

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: and EMOs, to identify a strategy for critical transportation

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: preservation including potential road elevations during 100,

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: 200, and 500 year flood levels compatible with the LTFS level

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: of protection goals. <bullet> Critical transportation and emergency services throughout

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: the basin are inconsistent with each other and fail to operate

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: effectively for a typical flood event.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Recommendation for Action 2B.12

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Minnesota and North Dakota should each explore the issues surrounding dedicating a portion of state aid for highway funding for culvert sizing and related road modifications that benefit basin flood damage reduction strategies and introduce legislation to change state law if necessary. The RRBC shall assist with facilitation the discussion and analysis, by the end of 2013.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Recommendation for Action 2B.13

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: An analysis of planned and proposed road elevations for 100, 200, and 500 year flood protection at township, county and state levels for emergency, population sustainability, and agricultural and economic production needs shall be developed. Engineering expertise funded and directed by the RRWMB, RRJWRD, and appropriate state agencies should identify needs by location and hydrologic impacts on flooding by change of flows, elevation of the flood stage, and other related impacts using the new LiDAR data.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Recommendation for Action 2B.14

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Minnesota and North Dakota should develop through their Departments of Transportation, a state and local funding strategy to assist in county and township flood-related road repairs and implement additional flood mitigation efforts once the protection goals are achieved and Federal emergency aid under a disaster declaration is less likely.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Recommendation for Action 2B.15

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: The RRBC should facilitate discussions with relevant regional organizations, state and Federal departments of transportation, and emergency management offices to identify a strategy for critical transportation preservation, including potential road elevations during the 100, 200, and 500 year flood levels, and to identify state and Federal funding needs.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: 2C Floodplain Management--Retention <bullet> No comprehensive, basin-wide strategy exists to implement

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: the LTFS minimum 20 percent flow reduction goal for the main

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: stem while achieving local tributary flood damage reduction. <bullet> The impacts of retention are often dependant on timing and

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: location. Not all sites are equally beneficial for local

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: tributary and basin main stem flood damage reduction. <bullet> Flow reduction through retention as demonstrated by modeling

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: can reduce flows and stages on the Red River main stem as well

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: as provide local benefits on tributaries. However, due to the

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: variability of flood events, retention must be used in

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: conjunction with other structural and non-structural measures

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: to achieve the LTFS goals that will result in basin-wide

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: improved levels of protection. <bullet> The minimum goal for flow reduction on the Red River main

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: stem at the international boundary for a 100 year flood equates

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: to around 1.5 million acre-feet of storage upstream accounting

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: for timing of flow and costing approximately $1.5 billion. <bullet> Retention using the minimum 20 percent flow reduction goal

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: basin-wide can be achieved over the next 20 years if local,

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: state, and Federal funds are leveraged to provide comprehensive

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: local, tributary and main stem benefits for residents,

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: property, and the environment. <bullet> Retention that will cumulatively achieve the basin minimum

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: 20 percent flow reductions over the next 20 to 25 years should

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: be managed to improve flood control, improve water quality,

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: include natural resource enhancement opportunities, and provide

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: potential water supply during extended droughts. <bullet> Numerous small, aged P.L. 83-566 flood control dams

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: throughout the basin could provide additional capacity for

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: flood storage retention with refurbishment.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Recommendation for Action 2C.1

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Federal funding should be provided for retention at $25 million per year or $500 million over the next 20 years, with Minnesota, North Dakota, and local governments providing cost share funding for retention to achieve a minimum 20 percent reduction in peak flows on the Red River.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Recommendation for Action 2C.2

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Cost for retention projects should be shared among Federal (50 to 75 percent), states of Minnesota and North Dakota (25 to 35 percent), and the RRWMB, RRJWRD and local water boards (10 to 25 percent) over a period of 20 years staying within the current local joint board two mil levy.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Recommendation for Action 2C.3

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: A review of federally operated reservoirs, identifying the potential for increased storage during flood events, should be conducted by USACE and state agencies, and Wildlife Management Areas by the USFWS, reporting to relevant state agencies and the RRRA.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Recommendation for Action 2C.4

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: The newly formed RRRA should work with each water management board to plan, design, and implement retention, to achieve 25 percent of the retention goal every 5 years for their respective areas, with the goal of achieving the minimum 20 percent flow reduction for the Red River main stem over 20-25 years.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Recommendation for Action 2C.5

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: A project prioritization methodology for the use of Federal funds reflecting local and main stem needs and benefits should be developed by the RRRA by 2012.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Recommendation for Action 2C.6

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: The permitting process for water retention projects should be coordinated by the RRRA and a Federal agency liaison in the basin working with appropriate state and Federal agencies to help streamline the process to decrease timelines for project implementation, allow a one-stop permitting process, and provide general permits for certain projects.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Recommendation for Action 2C.7

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: NRCS and/or the states of Minnesota and North Dakota should provide $400,000 to expand the Project Planning and Permit Evaluation demonstration project to the entire Red River basin through the International Water Institute as part of the USACE Basin Watershed Feasibility Study.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Recommendation for Action 2C.8

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Public outreach on retention programs and a survey to determine landowner interest in storing water on their land should be completed in 2 years by the RRWMB and RRJWRD (or the RRRA) to assist in future planning for retention projects and determine achievable timelines and cost expectations that correspond to local participation.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Recommendation for Action 2C.9

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Regarding the ongoing USACE Red River Basin-wide Feasibility Study:

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: 2C.9.1 The current ongoing study shall be continued with

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Federal funding at $1 million per year and corresponding $1

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: million non-Federal match.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: 2C.9.2 The updating of HMS (hydrologic modeling system) of

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: the remaining major watersheds should be completed by the end

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: of 2012. This modeling will provide the tools necessary to

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: identify retention projects on tributaries that provide local

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: benefits and cumulatively benefit the basin.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: 2C.9.3 Modeling of the remaining main stem Hydrologic

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Engineering Centers River Analysis System HEC-RAS reach to the

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Canadian border presently underway, including the work needed

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: to tie all the main stem reaches together into one model from

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: White Rock, South Dakota, to the Canadian border, should be

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: completed by the end of 2012.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: 2C.9.4 The HEC-RAS main stem model, in conjunction with the

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: new watershed HMS models, should be finalized in such a way

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: that they can be utilized to provide the basis for a RRRA

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: ``Project Prioritization Process'' needed for evaluating

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: proposed projects, their effectiveness, and downstream impacts

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: in contributing to the RRBC's flow reduction goals on the major

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: tributaries and Red River main stem.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Recommendation for Action 2C.10

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: NRCS, in conjunction the RRRA, shall evaluate P.L. 83-566 and other dams that have flood control capacity in the basin to determine the feasibility of restoration for the purpose of adding potential flood water retention storage, including the identification of specific structures for rehabilitation, specific strategies and funding necessary, and proposed timelines. NRCS shall issue its findings to the RRRA by September 30, 2012. Federal funding of up to $6 million is needed for the evaluation and an additional estimated $10-$15 million for refurbishment. 3. Information and Tools for Maximizing Efforts Going Forward <bullet> The Red River Basin, a vast geographic area of three states

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: and one Canadian province, has great need for cooperation

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: across boundaries for uniform data and information gathering

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: efforts, an understanding of our differences, and a shared

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: vision of what needs to be accomplished. <bullet> The current local, state, and Federal partnership in

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: comprehensive flood risk reduction strategies is disjointed and

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: operates in a piecemeal fashion. <bullet> Each flood varies, creating unique issues regarding

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: preparation and protection needs. <bullet> Levels of protection recommended by RRBC for the LTFS Report

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: will provide the safety net needed and allow for variations in

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: floods, weather, and forecasting. <bullet> Further improvements in flood forecasting such as new data

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: sets, modeling improvements, and real time information to

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: account for variables related to precipitation and temperature

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: are needed to build upon those instituted after the 1997 flood. <bullet> Additional efforts and information are needed as a guide for

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: the future as updated needs become evident.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Recommendation for Action 3.1

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: The RRBC shall, for the next 10 years, conduct an annual evaluation of flood mitigation progress towards the implementation of the LTFS Report Recommendations. This evaluation shall be submitted to Minnesota, North Dakota, South Dakota, and Manitoba.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Recommendation for Action 3.2

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Jurisdictional Multi-Boundary Coordination should be implemented wherever possible through the RRBC.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: 3.2.1 The Minnesota, North Dakota, and South Dakota

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: governors and the Manitoba Premier should meet at least once

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: every 2 years, along with the relevant legislative committee

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: chairs of the state and provincial governments, to receive an

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: update on progress towards the LTFS recommendations on flood

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: reduction strategies, water quality, water quantity, and other

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: relevant natural resource issues.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: 3.2.2 With the assistance of RRBC, the International

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Legislators Forum among Manitoba, Minnesota, North Dakota, and

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: South Dakota legislators should be continued to discuss current

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: topics, including flood risk reduction strategies.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: 3.2.3 Minnesota should coordinate through the Board of Water

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: and Soil Resources and the state legislature the inclusion of

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: all subwatersheds on the Minnesota side as Watershed Districts

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: (Ottertail) and membership in the RRWMB (Ottertail and Buffalo-

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Red Watershed District).

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: 3.2.4 Federal agencies should utilize their regional

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: structures in innovative new ways to accommodate Red River

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: basin hydrologic boundaries.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: 3.2.5 When necessary, RRBC shall coordinate a jurisdictional

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: meeting of heads of state, legislative leaders, and key agency

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: officials to prompt dialogue and development of unified action

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: on such issues.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Recommendation for Action 3.3

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: LTFS should be expanded to include the entire Red River basin:

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: 3.3.1 Manitoba should continue funding RRBC's efforts to

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: model the 20 percent flow reduction strategy in Manitoba and

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: also continue and accelerate the gathering of Light Detection

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: and Ranging (LiDAR) data, at $70,000 through 2012.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: 3.3.2 South Dakota and local leadership should determine the

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: feasibility of establishing watershed organizations in Roberts

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: and Marshall counties through the International Legislators

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Forum within the next 2 years.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Recommendation for Action 3.4

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: RRBC should coordinate development of a basin-wide strategy and identification of funding sources for improving flood forecasting during 2012 among local, state, provincial, and Federal agencies.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: 3.4.1 The generation of relevant time appropriate data (real

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: time rain and snowmelt, soil moisture, frost depth information,

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: and other information) and improved modeling through a

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: volunteer network and the development of a real time network

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: shall be addressed.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: 3.4.2 The feasibility of establishing an on-site decision

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: support service to the region during spring and summer flood

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: events by hosting a U.S. National Weather Service hydrologist

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: in the basin shall be considered, as well as identifying a

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: funding source for such an effort.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Recommendation for Action 3.5

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: The USGS, RRWMB, RRJWRD, and their member water boards, NDSWC, MNDNR, and other key stakeholders, should develop a stream gage strategy by 2012 with associated costs and funders for the basin for the main stem Red River and its tributaries that will support the new hydrologic and hydraulic models that will provide a long term record for accurate, timely, and consistent flow data for model development, aid in flood reduction strategies, and include water quality modeling needs in the next 2 years.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Recommendation for Action 3.6

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: RRBC should update the LTFS Report in 2021 with the inclusion of Manitoba and South Dakota and shared funding from the four jurisdictions. 4. Resources to Implement <bullet> Minnesota and North Dakota, cost-sharing with local, state,

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: and Federal funds, should implement actions consistent with the

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: LTFS to maintain the basin's social, economic, and

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: environmental welfare and protection from future large floods,

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: as this investment over the next 10 years will significantly

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: reduce the risk of $11-$13 billion in losses from a large flood

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: and protect the economic output of the basin.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Recommendations for Action 4.1

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: The States of Minnesota and North Dakota, cost-sharing with local and Federal partners, should make a financial investment of about $3.54 billion over the next 10 years to immediately address flooding in the basin with a structural approach.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: 4.1 Funding in Minnesota needed for the next 10 years is

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: $270.9 million, from local and state sources.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: 4.2 Funding in North Dakota needed for the next 10 years is

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: $536.4 million from local and state sources.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: 4.3 Local funding at the RRWMB and RRJWRD levels should be

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: increased and maintained at a two mil levy.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: See attached funding timeline table D-31 and Level of

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Protection Appendix D, D-3.1, p. 12 with state, local and

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Federal funds.

Notes: \1\ The estimated amounts of the Federal and non-Federal Fargo/Moorhead LPP Diversion project total costs are based on the Fargo-Moorhead Metropolitan Area Flood Risk Management project Supplemental Draft Feasibility Report and Environmental Impact Statement, April 2011. Final cost-sharing amounts between the non-Federal partners have not yet been determined. \2\ Additional local protection included as a part of the Fargo-Moorhead LPP North Dakota diversion project cost listed under Fargo and Moorhead at the top of this table. \3\ Tolna Coulee cost includes $14 million for the control structure to prevent significant erosion in case of a natural overflow. \4\ Cost-sharing for raising railroad embankment at Devils Lake estimated to be \1/3\ cost-shared by Burlington Northern Santa Fe Railway, \1/3\ by Amtrak, and \1/3\ by the North Dakota Department of Transportation through a U.S. Department of Transportation grant. \5\ Federal participation in potential upstream storage projects is assumed to be available through future U.S. farm bill at approximately 50 percent cost-sharing; however, actual Federal funding availability and cost-sharing amounts is uncertain. Also, implementation of projects in each state is assumed to be at comparable levels, however this will depend on project implementation schedules by each state. \6\ Operation and maint[enance] (O&M) costs of projects are not included in this tabulation, even though in some cases the O&M costs may be substantial. O&M costs are typically a non-Federal or local responsibility and should also be considered in the implementation decision for a project. \7\ Information on specific projects at individual communities can be found on the City Assessment tables in Appendix C. \8\ Funding for farmstead and rural ring dikes depend on the number of landowners requesting assistance. A rough estimate based on funding from recent years is included.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Sub-committee observations:

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Tile has potential to be used as a water management tool in the Red River Basin. Experts from North Dakota State University, the Energy and Environmental Research Center, the tiling industry, International Water Institute and private landowners have conducted or are working on short-term studies on this type of water management. The preliminary findings show a need for further evaluation and study.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: There appears to be the potential to gain efficiencies in water retention, protect public safety, improve soil health and water quality. There are some studies indicating the soil can hold more water in the spring, but these studies are not conclusive. Many of the reports on water management efficiencies are anecdotal and need to be further studied by the scientific community. The potential is real, but we need to be certain we are not solving one water resource issue while creating another. Retention Committee Permitting Sub-committee Chad L. Engels, Chairman

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Sub-Committee Recommendations: <bullet> EPA Guideline Change[:]

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: <ctr-circle> EPA 404(b)(1) Guidelines, set out in 40 CFR section

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: 230 (LEDPA)--404(b)(1) states a permit will not be issued

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: ``if there is a practicable alternative to the proposed

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: discharge which would have less adverse impact on the

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: aquatic ecosystem, so long as the alternative does not have

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: other significant adverse environmental consequences.'' Our

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: subcommittee has identified LEDPA as a significant obstacle

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: to building retention projects in terms of time and money.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: A solution would be to replace The Least Environmental

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Damaging Practicable Alternative (LEDPA) requirement with a

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: simple environmental mitigation requirement for the

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: proposed project. <bullet> SAMP[:]

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: <ctr-circle> EPA 404 Nationwide Permit/Regional Permit--Currently,

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: retention projects must be permitted as individual

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: projects. Our subcommittee has learned that many categories

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: of projects are permitted under what are called

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: ``Nationwide Permits'' or ``Regional permits''. These

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: permit categories speed the process significantly by having

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: a common ``Purpose and Need'' and ``Description of Proposed

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: Alternatives and No Action Alternative'' in the EIS

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: requirements for flood retention projects covered by this

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: national or regional permit. Therefore, our subcommittee

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: will likely recommend that a Nationwide Permit (preferable)

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: or Regional General Permit (second choice) be developed for

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: three categories of retention projects in the Red River of

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: the North Watershed. These project categories include Off-

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: like the Maple River Dam, and wetland retention projects

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: that temporarily store water above the delineated wetland

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Finney

Statement.paragraph: boundary.
